Award.AwardTitle: Development of a 21st Century Industrial Process Operations Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
To assure that manufacturing, mining, biochemical, pulp and paper, power generation, oil and gas, water treatment, and food and beverage industries in Northern Minnesota remain globally competitive, it is vital that industrial technicians and process operators be prepared with the skills and knowledge required to help these industries thrive. This project at Itasca Community College in Minnesota is timely as the current workforce in the region is aging, and it has become recognized by regional industries that a workforce pipeline is needed to maintain current operations and facilitate future growth. It is designed to develop an Associate in Applied Science (AAS) program in Process Operations that will capitalize on the need these industries have for highly-qualified and motivated employees. The program is a shift from the current industry specific technical programs of the region to a program that is focused on developing graduates who are prepared to be 21st century workers for these industries. This will increase the regional economic vitality and help the college remain a model of progressive instruction. Partners include industries such as Minnesota Power, Lonza, Blandin Paper Company, Marvin Windows and Doors, and American Sugar as well as the high schools in the vicinity of the college. The overall curriculum will be industry driven through its development and will remain responsive to the industrial fluctuations in the region by maintaining and utilizing strong industry ties. The college will become a member of the North American Process Technology Alliance (NAPTA) that can provide curriculum and access to model programs as well as an avenue for project dissemination.

This Associate in Applied Science (AAS) program in process operations will encompass a broad scope of industrial plant operations to educate and motivate future industrial technicians by utilizing a structured learning community to deliver a condensed one-and-a-half year curriculum. To maximize the chance for success, students will be required to have prerequisite courses in industrial safety, welding, machining, fabrication, computing, and mathematics. To provide students multiple pathways, students may enter the program from one of four pathways (a summer boot camp, high school credits developed for this project, industrial work experience, or relevant college courses and experiences.) It will develop ties to local school districts through "College-In-The-Schools" curriculum development and take advantage of industry partners through site visits, capstone projects, and adjunct industry-based instructors. The areas of student development and assessment will be technical knowledge (what students know), professionalism (who students are), and process awareness (what students can do). The nationally recognized pre-engineering program at the college will serve as a model for this new AAS Process Operations program. Model tenents will be utilization of Project Based Learning (PBL), industry tours, industry professionals serving as instructors or guest speakers, student learning communities, and student ownership of and pride in the program. The two established and growing Industrial Technologies programs in Power Generation and Pulp and Paper at the college have laid the groundwork for this more broadly applicable AAS Process Operations program in terms of infrastructure, curriculum, and industry ties. A comprehensive evaluation process will be used to assess and improve this AAS in Process Operations program during its formation and execution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Itasca Community College

Development of a 21st Century Industrial Process Operations Program

National Science Foundation Grant No. 1700558

Outcomes Executive Summary

The Itasca Community College?s (ICC) Process Operations program was originally created based on the requests and inputs from a consortium of local industry leaders and quasigovernmental organizations to help address the employee recruitment and training challenges facing the area?s process industries, including:

  • Aging workforce and mass retirements
  • Employers no longer had the luxury of having 10-12yrs. to develop operator skills
  • The need for an accelerated program for skills enhancement or retraining
  • A career pathway for people newly entering the workforce.
  • To provide a trained and effective employee base for potential new industrial process facilities.

The ICC Industrial Technologies group developed the new Industrial Process Operations Program (IPOP) drawing from its previous experience with two industry and customer specific focused training programs; Pulp & Paper Manufacturing and Power Generation programs. The new program development was predicated on meeting several criteria, including:

  • Universality: The skills developed had to be applicable to all process industries
  • Reality: The program had to utilize equipment, systems and procedures found in industry with a hands-on skills development approach
  • Challenging: Develop operations skills utilizing a three-tier approach; understanding the fundamentals, application/critical thinking, project-based learning
  • Speed: Complete an AAS qualified program in 18 months

The program as developed is separated into three ?Skills Tracks?:

  • Professional Skills: Concentrated on the soft skills (e.g., safety, environmental, communication, teamwork, computer skills, etc.) utilizing existing ICC programs and curriculum.
  • Process Skills: Newly created curriculum concentrating on industrial processes (e.g., boilers, separation, distillation, etc.), Process Control and Control Strategies.
  • Technical Skills: Newly created curriculum concentrating on process equipment (e.g., valves, pumps, exchangers, etc.), Testing (IR, vibration, sampling etc.), process troubleshooting, and the hands on skills required for process operators.

The final semester is dedicated to developing, planning and executing a project for a local industry partner. We?ve completed multiple Capstone projects for Minnesota Power.

The program success can be measured by our greater than 98% industry placement for our graduates.

 

Program Evolution

The original program development centered around a dedicated four semester AAS level curriculum delivered over an eighteen-month schedule. During the first 12-24 months of the program the plan was proceeding well. However, as the first couple of cohorts was entering into the final stages of the program the area economic and employment conditions changed significantly, as a consequence the majority of our students were hired out of the program prior to completion and the area industries returned to a ?mass? hiring and training on the job model.

As a result of the changes to the economic picture, the Process Operations faculty with assistance and guidance of the Northeast Higher Education District (NHED) customized training group (AdvancED MN) refocused the program format/curriculum into a customizable package available to the local industries to assist in enhancing and accelerating new or returning employees? skills development.

This program realignment has resulted in partnering with an international iron mining facility to create a complete upgrade/new training program for their induration area control room operators. The scope of the project integrating curriculum, competency testing and critical thinking exercises to establish a superior level of operator expertise. Much of the curriculum format, competency and critical thinking techniques are a direct outcome/result of the work supported by the NSF grant. The industrial partner has begun implementing the training program completed so far and has expanded the scope to include additional areas.

We continue to explore partnerships with additional local industrial facilities and have made our developed curriculum materials available to other Minnesota higher education facilities.

The curriculum developed as part of this NSF grant has been uploaded to the ATE Central website and is available free of charge.

 

Training Capabilities/Packages:

Process Equipment: e.g., Pumps, Valves, Exchangers

Basic Processes: e.g., Blending, Separation, Water Treatment, Distillation, Boilers, etc.

HMI Based Process Operations: e.g., Navigation, Process Adjustments, Alarm Handling, Trending, etc.

Process Troubleshooting: e.g., Mechanical Faults, Instrumentation Issues, Control Issues, etc.

Fundamentals of Process Control: Common Process Control Strategies, e.g., PID-FB, Cascade, Ratio, Feedforward, Basic Loop Tuning, etc.

Operator Rounds: e.g., Procedures, Data Collection, Reporting & Analyses, etc.

Operating Procedures (SOP?s): e.g., Understanding, Analyzing, Developing and Modifying SOP?s, Equipment Mgt, Maintenance Support, etc.

Operator Lead Reliability (OLR): e.g., IR, Vibration, Ultrasonic, Lubrication Monitoring, etc.

Principles of Basic Quality Control: e.g., Lab Sample Collection and Basic Chemical Testing e.g., pH, Turbidity, Cl, ORP, TDS, etc.

Operator Communications: e.g., Shift Reports, Radio Communications, Work Orders, etc.
